job_title: Head of Department in Manchester, England
pros: Friendly, positive team, trusted, supported
cons: One size fits all. Poor pay for tutors

job_title: Teacher in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: Friendly staff Starbucks on site
cons: Poor management Disorganised Too many sites

pros: CPD opportunities, some of the people from library team, variety of responsibilities within the role
cons: Low pay - the company strategy revolves around increasing income from student course fees and cutting costs regardless of the impact this has on quality of learning. The money that is made/saved stays at the top, and wages of staff who do "the work" stays low. Understaffed so you're run off your feet a lot and the HE libraries tend to take a back seat in favour of managing behaviour of students in FE. Flat structure of the team means that some do more than others and do not get recognition for it. Senior management have no real knowledge of academic libraries and librarianship, which feeds into their reasoning for having a flat structure, but also means that they have a high staff turnover and students don't get the quality of support that they really need.

job_title: Employability & Partnership Coordinator in Manchester, England
pros: Good stepping ladder for future roles.
cons: High turnover of staff so sense of direction is missing.

pros: Wonderful team to work with
cons: Unrealistic targets and poor communication with staff

pros:
It was the sole responsibility of tutors who went above and beyond to ensure students had the best education without management's support.
Some colleagues were highly supportive, which helped you get through the day.
cons: I taught there for a decade, and the culture of management bullying was the worst experience of my life. It was nothing short of toxic. The lies, deceit and cover-ups were beyond belief. There was no integrity in recruiting students. I should have gone to press, but I knew it would end in my dismissal. Eventually, I moved on and never looked back.

pros: Some good colleagues. Better before it merged
cons: Way too many to list. including bare face lying to force employees from positions they no longer want to fund there are no depths this company will go to achieve their goal of making money

pros: Great colleges who get the students through in spite of the management
cons: Bullying culture, appalling management, toxic working environment

pros: City centre location so good transport links

pros: Colleagues are great to work with

pros: Flexible working, strong, competent and supportive management, competitive pay and leave, diverse, progressive, good progression routes, nice colleagues, pay increments every year

review_title: A good place to work as long as employees are given the correct support
job_title: Departmental Team Leader in Manchester, England
pros: Colleagues within and external to the department.
cons: Heavy staff absence and lack of management within the department

pros: Some students and the wonderful ladies at the cantine.
cons: The staff is horrendous, they worry more about the numbers than the actual students. They allow, and almost force students who committed crime to come back into college just to embellish the statistics.

pros: Get involved, work hard, good facilities.
cons: Some campuses have great facilities, others don't have such good facilities. It depends where you work as to what is available to you.

pros:
I taught at TMC for 2 years as a NQT and gained invaluable experience - due to being thrown in at the deep end (twice) but invaluable nonetheless.
Regular CPD (although I presume this was due to the pending ofsted visit)
cons:
Permanent staff who have been there years get an increment annually and can’t be bothered whereas new and keen tutors get passed around like toys on temporary contracts with no view to permanent employment. 
The working environment is extremely stressful with unrealistic targets and overcrowded classrooms. Poor behaviour is not addressed leading to further of the same and the good students suffer. 
Classes are not differentiated in language ability so tutors are expected to wave the magic wand to ‘support and stretch and challenge’. 
If you start be aware that you most definitely won’t get paid for at least 3 months then not get paid correctly. There seems to be a massive gap in communication between management and HR. 
The company and management do not appreciate their staff and there is a massive lack of structure and organisation leading to de motivation and poor standardisation. 
Staff are most certainly not valued or recognised. 
Students DO NOT come first, funding comes first. Tutors are expected to place students on higher qualifications that are beyond their capabilities and add additional units to create more funding for the college. I understand it’s a business but this adds a lot of extra pressure on the already overworked staff.

pros: People, diversity, students, support and
cons: Poor inexperienced management with no understanding of how to support staff and listen to their concerns and action them appropriately

pros: Well organized and welcoming teachers
cons: No problems. Everything is good

pros: Good vibrant place to work
cons: Nothing comes to mind overall good place

pros: Staff and students were good to work with.
cons: You get on well if you're a good brown nose type. The only problem is everyone can see this which effects moral and makes staff less committed. Anyone in line with teaching staff or below never get the support from their direct managers and always made to feel undervalued. These managers are dangerous and very selfish. Also I've never know so many care taking staff who call themselves managers who just like to tell people what to do as opposing to getting stuck in themselves. This type of management practice is all to common throughout the college which has completely written off staff moral and made it a horrible place to work.

pros: Most of the people I work with are great and the students are brilliant.
cons:
I work as a tutor/assessor and a bad place to work for has just gotten worse.  The hours are long, mountains of paperwork, no moral, no thanks, terrible I.T. system that's just not fit for purpose and terrible upper management that rely on bullying.  My main manager is giving their best and working 80/90 hour weeks for no thanks and a whole lot of abuse.  We recently had an internal audit and we couldn't have scored worse, literally.

Most of the staff are resigned to the apprenticeship unit going under and are actively seeking alternative employment before the inevitable.

If you have the chance to work for The Manchester College.  Don't.  Go somewhere else.

pros: None.  If I had to choose though, I would say the cleaners who deserve more recognition and respect.
cons: Joined in 2011 and left in 2018.  I saw this college decline in the hands of a regime that bullied staff.  Learners are a vessel to funding and do not come first.  Funding was claimed through fraudulent means and often at the learners expense.  Paperwork is often lost and signatures forged.  I made the right decision leaving that place.  If you aspire to be a teacher or tutor, look elsewhere for an employer who will value you!  TMC do not like people who can think and challenge management with a view to improving the learning experience.

review_title: Worst job you will ever have! Bullying is Allowed
pros:
Holidays
Leaving at the end of the working day
A couple of colleagues
Seeing the back of the place on a Friday.
cons:
Extremely poor and incompetent management team with disgusting attitudes, no management or industry experience. 
Bullying is condoned by the College and HR department. 
Absolutely no quality, standards or professionalism, learners on Level 3 courses with very little or no formal qualifications. Learners at TMC are not allowed to fail and somehow they don't, despite doing none of the work.
Dealing of drugs go unpunished, final contracts given over and over again.

pros: It's an ambitious college and if you're good at what you do, you will be recognised
cons: It works with many students from disadvantaged backgrounds and is rightly proud of that, however, it shouldn't be worried about reaching out for the highest performing students

pros: The students and staff. Talented and friendly. It's the only FE college IN Manchester so you have that prestige, Europe's largest etc. etc.
cons: Bullying is rife, you need a thick skin. You'll work more hours than there are in the day and it will not be recognised. You job will change every year and you'll have nothing to do with the decisions that are made which affect your work. Sexist. Low wages.

job_title: Tutor in Preston, North West England, England
pros: Early finishes on a Friday
cons: Rubbish pay! No opportunity to progress! Oppressive environment! Micro managed but senior management make more errors.

pros: Most of the people are lovely. Pension and hours are good.
cons: Very clicky environment, if your face fits your ok. I worked for the ltegroup and during my probation I have a mental breakdown due to personal issues. At the time I needed the most support I was fired.  There is sometimes a bulling atmosphere, which is not good. Some employees have been there for many years and haven’t moved with the times. They issue PIPS which puts  people under further stress. I wouldn’t step foot back in the place. They look after students mental needs but not the staff.

review_title: Very poor management and bullying culture.
pros: Very few pros,  this is definitely not a company to join.
cons: Terrible HR department.  Management generally only interested in their careers and dismissive of teachers.  Very little respect shown to teaching staff.  Very poor practice generally, inadequate staff training and particularly  bad practice towards students with special education needs

pros: If you have connections in there you may go far
cons: Lack of resources, time restricted, no real progression unless you have so called friends in there.

pros: Rewarding working with offenders to help them achieve life and academic skills to help them achieve on release from prison.  Good environment to gain experience with learners that present with different learning needs.
cons: Lack of time non-contact time to prepare resources and mark / assess learners work places immense pressure on you.

review_title: The worst educational facility I have ever worked at.
pros:
Some nice colleagues.
If you're desperate for a job, and on the verge of homelessness, then work here, in any other circumstance- run for it!
cons:
Completely toxic work environment
Autocrat management styles are endemic (lots of shouting, table slamming, intimidation tactics etc.)
You have to copy everyone into email to 'cover your back'
Blame culture is rife here.

cons:
Internal communication between departments was not always great
Opportunities for internal progression were often limited
Few added benefits for employees

pros: Loved my team and the extended colleagues I worked with.
cons: Terrible management, poor facilities, too spread out across the city, too much travel.

pros: Nice team to work with.
